Based on my search results, I can provide you with information about "Folwark zwierzęcy" (Animal Farm) and its context in Polish literature, though I didn't find specific direct connections to Stanisław Lem and Czesław Miłosz in the search results.

## "Folwark zwierzęcy" - Overview

"Folwark zwierzęcy" is a novel by English journalist and writer George Orwell, depicting farm animals that expelled humans and began ruling the farm themselves. It is an allegorical representation of Stalinism and a warning against any totalitarianism.

## Publication History in Poland

"The first Polish edition, translated by Teresa Jeleńska, was published in exile in London in 1947 under the title 'Zwierzęcy folwark.'"(no content)"Almost until the fall of the communist system in Poland in 1989, this was a novel banned by censorship – its first official domestic edition was published only in 1988."

## Literary Context and Polish Writers

While the search results mention "Polish writers who undoubtedly deserved this title: Bruno Schulz, Stanisław Ignacy Witkiewicz, Eliza Orzeszkowa, Władysław Reymont" in the context of notable authors, and reference "Czesław Miłosz" appearing in educational materials alongside other literary works, the search didn't yield specific information about the direct influence or reception of "Folwark zwierzęcy" on or by Stanisław Lem and Czesław Miłosz specifically.

## Literary Significance

"Orwell constructs an extended, prosaic, satirical and parabolic fable... The key and power of parable and fable lies in the fact that when we laugh at or despise Orwell's four-legged heroes - we laugh at ourselves and despise our own human race... The story about animals created by Orwell wonderfully illustrates certain historical patterns and truths about human nature."

The search results show that "Folwark zwierzęcy" is recognized as an important work in Polish literary discourse, though specific scholarly analysis of its influence on or reception by the mentioned Polish writers would require more specialized academic sources.
